name: Impostor Professor Oak

historicalClassification.note: Originally printed as a Trainer in Base Set. Would be classified as Supporter by modern rules due to affecting opponent's hand.

effect.text: Your opponent shuffles his or her hand into his or her deck, then draws 7 cards.

antiSynergies: Most strategies - generally helps opponent too much
tips: Best when opponent has a large hand of key cards
Can backfire by giving opponent fresh cards
Only use if opponent has 9+ cards in hand
Generally considered one of the worst rare cards in Base Set

competitiveHistory: Impostor Professor Oak is infamous in competitive Pokemon TCG as one of the most overrated cards by new players. While hand disruption sounds appealing in theory, giving your opponent 7 fresh cards almost always benefits them more than it hurts them. Competitive players quickly identified it as a trap card and avoided it entirely. The card became a running joke in the community and an educational example of why giving your opponent resources is generally a bad idea.

rulings.ruling: Your opponent must shuffle their entire hand into their deck
Your opponent then draws exactly 7 cards
If your opponent has fewer than 7 cards in their deck, they draw as many as possible and do not lose the game until they cannot draw at their next turn
This effect is mandatory once played; you cannot choose not to have opponent draw 7
The shuffling and drawing are both part of the single effect
Your opponent cannot choose not to shuffle or draw
Any cards in your opponent's hand are shuffled in, regardless of their content
This does not count as your opponent's draw for their turn
Cards drawn this way can be played immediately if it's your turn and you play other cards afterward
